prior_works.authors: George E. P. Box and George C. Tiao
prior_works.relationship_sentence: AERCA’s definition of anomalies as interventions on the data-generating process directly builds on Box–Tiao’s intervention analysis view of shocks as exogenous perturbations to time series.

prior_works.title: Grouped graphical Granger modeling for gene networks
prior_works.relationship_sentence: AERCA extends sparse Granger causal discovery ideas exemplified by grouped-lasso VAR, but augments them by explicitly modeling the innovation (exogenous) distributions to enable root cause identification.

prior_works.relationship_sentence: The insight that identification comes from the distributional properties of exogenous shocks in SVAR directly inspires AERCA’s strategy to model the normal distribution of exogenous variables and detect deviations as root causes.

prior_works.title: Neural Granger Causality
prior_works.relationship_sentence: AERCA builds on neural Granger causal discovery as a baseline capability, but goes beyond it by integrating causal discovery with explicit exogenous-noise modeling for root cause analysis.

prior_works.relationship_sentence: TCDF informs AERCA’s causal discovery component, yet AERCA addresses TCDF’s limitation by linking discovered Granger causes to exogenous interventions to perform root cause identification.

synthesis_narrative: AERCA’s intellectual lineage fuses classic Granger causality with intervention-based views of anomalies and modern learnable causal discovery. The foundation is Granger’s 1969 definition of temporal causality, which AERCA explicitly learns among variables and then exploits for attribution. Box and Tiao’s intervention analysis provides the conceptual bridge to anomaly-centric reasoning: viewing irregular events as exogenous shocks to the generative mechanism. Building practical discovery machinery draws on sparse Granger frameworks such as Lozano et al.’s grouped-lasso VAR, which established identifiable, scalable Granger graph recovery in high dimensions. Hyvärinen et al.’s SVAR work is a key inspiration for AERCA’s core innovation: modeling the distributional properties of exogenous shocks. By characterizing the innovations under normal conditions, AERCA can flag departures as the sources of observed anomalies, paralleling the idea that non-Gaussian or distributional structure of shocks enables identification. Modern neural approaches—Tank et al.’s Neural Granger Causality and Nauta et al.’s TCDF—inform AERCA’s differentiable causal discovery component, but neither links discovered structure to exogenous-intervention deviations for root cause analysis. Finally, graph-based anomaly detectors like GDN expose a gap: they model dependencies for detection but lack causal direction and principled attribution. AERCA directly addresses this by jointly discovering Granger-causal structure and learning normal innovation distributions, enabling precise, causally grounded root cause identification.
